title: Small Things, Great Stewardship
devotional:
Old Mr. Abernathy, the church's oldest member, shuffled into the sanctuary every Sunday morning, a worn leather-bound Bible clutched in his trembling hands. He wasn't a preacher, or a singer, or even particularly gifted at conversation. But Mr. Abernathy was the church's self-appointed 'caretaker.' He arrived early to straighten the hymnals, water the wilting potted plant by the pulpit, and ensure the offering plates were polished and ready. Some whispered he was a bit eccentric, obsessed with details no one else noticed.

One sweltering summer afternoon, a group of volunteers gathered to discuss a much-needed renovation of the church's aging kitchen. Ideas flew: new appliances, updated countertops, fresh paint. The cost estimates, however, were daunting. The church's coffers were already strained. Discouragement settled like a heavy blanket. Then, Mr. Abernathy, silent until that moment, cleared his throat. He spoke of the years he'd diligently saved, sacrificing small comforts, driven by a conviction to use his resources for God's glory and he presented a substantial sum. "It ain't much," he rasped, "but it's what I could do. The Lord's kitchen needs fixin'."

Mr. Abernathy's story reminds us that stewardship isn't just about grand gestures or large donations. It's about the faithful management of all that God has entrusted to us, no matter how seemingly small. It's about recognizing that our time, talents, and treasures are not our own, but gifts to be used for His purposes. In the heat of summer, when the garden is growing, are we investing in the soil? Are we watering the harvest? Is our energy being used to grow and produce for the future?

True stewardship transforms us from passive consumers into active participants in God's kingdom. It invites us to see every resource – a kind word, a helping hand, a spare hour – as an opportunity to reflect His love and advance His mission. The kitchen was renovated, and the church thrived, not only because of Mr. Abernathy's financial gift but because of the lesson he embodied: that faithful stewardship, in its simplest form, can yield extraordinary results.
image_description: A close-up shot of a worn, leather-bound Bible resting on a polished wooden church pew.
insights: The parable of the talents in Matthew 25:14-30 illustrates the principle of stewardship. Each servant was given talents according to their ability and was expected to invest them wisely. The servant who buried his talent was condemned, not because he lost it, but because he failed to use it for his master's benefit. This highlights that stewardship involves responsibility, initiative, and a willingness to take risks for God's kingdom. Also, the concept of the tithe is introduced and it helps people practice stewardship in their lives.
prayer: Gracious God, forgive me for the times I've been careless with the gifts You've entrusted to me. Help me to recognize that everything I have is a blessing from You, to be used for Your glory. Grant me the wisdom to manage my time, talents, and resources faithfully, and the courage to invest them in ways that will advance Your kingdom. In Jesus' name, Amen.
reflection: What resources has God entrusted to you? Are you using them to their full potential for His glory? What is one small step you can take today to be a more faithful steward of what you have?
